Jolie Holland's luxurious jazz vocals are a compelling match for her considerably

body: Jazz Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music. His quartet includes the saxophonist John O'Gallagher, the bassist Drew Gress and the drummer Tom
title: The Listings

body: A sport utility vehicle in which Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly was a passenger was involved in a three-car accident on a slick Brooklyn highway on Wednesday night, though no injuries were reported, the police said. One vehicle was badly damaged in the multiple-car collision, which the police said occurred about 8 p.m. near the 65th Street
title: Police Leader Unhurt After Accident

body: Good evening, snow-globe city. You survived the great post-Christmas whiteout of 2010. You frolicked and/or shoveled. You made molasses-on-snow. Now, perhaps, you can relax. Unless you're trying to get home. The trains and buses and subways are still messed up. For specifics on your evening commute, see below. And while you wait, try the
title: CITY ROOM;What Happens When a Plow Gets Stuck

body: SALUTING the new year huddled around the hearth with family and friends -- bedecked in sequins and plastic ''2011'' spectacles, spilling warm Champagne on the sofa -- is good, old-fashioned fun. But wouldn't you rather spend the night with Patti Smith? Whether you're bidding 2010 a hearty, don't-let-the-door-hit-you-on-the-way-out farewell or
title: Beyond Popping Corks, The Sounds of the New Year

body: IN an aluminum shed among postcard orchards in Columbia County in New York, Derek Grout inspected a collecting tank of his state-of-the-art copper-pot still. A blocked vent had caused the tank to buckle. ''I'm just kind of glad we didn't kill ourselves,'' he said with a laugh. ''Got to bang that out.'' He has been working with it for only two
title: Just Don't Call It Moonshine

body: FLOWERS are blooming in the dead of winter on the fringes of Brooklyn. Inside Lindsey Gamble's bakery, an out-of-the-way, nearly hidden storefront at President and Columbia Streets near the waterfront, butter cream tiers and gum paste orchids climb high. A pile of blue fondant Tiffany boxes seems to tip precariously beside an edible high-heel shoe
title: Brooklyn's Allure? Fancy Cakes, Dahling

body: SONGWRITERS have been translating heartache into melody for centuries, scoring the human condition with weather-worn notebooks and battered guitars. As the Irish folk singer Frank Harte once said, ''Those in power write the history, while those who suffer write the songs.'' In Brooklyn, at least, they don't have to suffer alone. At the Brooklyn
title: Heartaches and Harmonies

body: FOR a place selling beer and pulled pork sliders, the Brooklyneer has provoked a lot of controversy. This new bar is dedicated to all things Brooklyn, particularly, the menu declares, the borough's ''newly-emerging food artisans.'' There are Brooklyn hot dogs and Brooklyn pickles and Brooklyn whiskey. You can order toast points spread with Boerum
title: Brooklyn: The Brand

title: CITY ROOM; Celebrating Twisted Taxidermy

title: The Listings

title: The Listings

title: The Listings

body: Calling your new-music festival Darmstadt Essential Repertoire is a conscious provocation on multiple levels, as the New York composers Zach Layton and Nick Hallett surely realized when they chose the name. It alludes to the Darmstadt International Summer Courses for New Music, a venerable and formidable German laboratory for avant-garde
title: MUSIC REVIEW; Celebrating New Music, Just Off the Beaten Path

body: Television Neil Genzlinger The documentary ''NEW YORK STREET GAMES'' (WLIW, Sunday, 5:30 p.m.), about stickball and other recreations once common in the city's neighborhoods, is one warm bit of nostalgia after another. But it reaches a wonderfully wistful high point when, about 20 minutes in, the celebrities, public officials and other aficionados
title: The Week Ahead: Nov. 28-Dec. 4

body: Classical Steve Smith Among classical-music aficionados, Darmstadt is a name to conjure with. Short for the Darmstadt International Summer Courses for New Music, a long-running German laboratory for contemporary composers, the reference invokes high-minded Modernist rigor for proponents, inflexible Serialist dogma to detractors. That the New York
title: THE WEEK AHEAD | NOV. 28-DEC. 4

body: Suppose you'd rather let someone else do the baking? Here are some bakeries that will allow New Yorkers to fetch and carry instead of roll and crimp: BENOIT 60 West 55th Street, (646) 943-7373. A pumpkin pie with a French-style filling is $20, available on two hours' notice every day from Nov. 22. BLUE SMOKE BAKE SHOP 116 East 27th Street, (212)
title: Bakeries Happy to Do It for You

body: San Francisco THE idea for a pie-centric restaurant came to Trevor Logan in the California desert. He was in the midst of planning an ice cream parlor when he had what may have been a flash of insight, a stroke of genius or a psychic message from his 90-year-old grandmother in Oklahoma: ''Maybe I shouldn't just be doing ice cream,'' he thought.
title: Pie to Cupcake: Time's Up

body: Help for a Queens Co-Op The first Queens food co-op is planned in Long Island City. There will be a fund-raiser tonight from 6 to 9 at the Foundry, 42-38 Ninth Street, Long Island City, $30 for food, $50 with drinks: queensharvestcoop.com. Talking About Fish Scientists, writers and anglers will participate in a panel discussion on Thursday about
title: Calendar

author: James Verini is a writer in New York. This is his first article for the magazine.
body: One night in July 2003, a little before midnight, a plainclothes N.Y.P.D. detective, investigating a series of car thefts in upper Manhattan, followed a suspicious-looking young man with long, stringy hair and a nose ring into the A.T.M. lobby of a bank. Pretending to use one of the machines, the detective watched as the man pulled a debit card
title: The Hacker Who Went Into The Cold

The single ''Hope There's Someone,'' a stark, breath-catching lamentation on death and the afterlife, gorgeously bellowed over
title: The Listings

body: Anyone who has been lost in the last few weeks around the southern reaches of the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn could be excused for experiencing a powerful Koch administration flashback. On the wall of a brick warehouse there, visible from the parking lot of a furniture store, a huge mural unfurls itself, a loving, seemingly spray-by-spray re-creation
title: Now Everyone Can Read the Writing on the Wall

body: BENKERT--Ernst G.,82, died October 5th, 2010 after living for three and a half years with angiosarcoma, a rare form of cancer. With him at the end were his children, Louly Williams and Edward Benkert, his grandchildren, Ellie and Max Williams, and his companion of twenty-eight years, Alexandra Walcott. He is also survived by a brother, Kyle
title: Paid Notice: Deaths BENKERT, ERNST G.

body: In 1881, New York's special committee on Effluvium Nuisances reported that ''intolerable stenches'' were coming from the area known as Newtown Creek. On its banks were mills and offal rendering shops, oil refineries and fertilizer factories. Over the years, industry thrived in the area, leaving tons of toxic residues. The federal government is
title: EDITORIAL; A Long Wait for a Clean Creek

His
title: The Listings

body: HE was a pioneer nonpareil in that virtual wasteland once known as the Lower West Side, long before real estate brokers had the opportunity to market it as the ''Gold Coast of TriBeCa.'' Now, after 50 years in the neighborhood, Mardig Kachian, a sculptor, is leaving for Brooklyn. It was in 1960 that Mr. Kachian, now 73, moved into 179 West Street,
title: BIG DEAL; Make Him an Offer That He'll Accept

body: Pop Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. Bell X1 (Thursday) Tremendously popular in its native Ireland, this quartet's glazy, melodic alt-rock recalls the quasi-experimental yawning of Coldplay. And while it's occasionally derided for its seeming dedication to mildness, the band did record a long, contemplative song about the drama
title: The Listings

body: The Bloomberg administration wants to invest up to $1.5 billion over the next 20 years on new environmental techniques to reduce the flow of sewage into the city's waterways. The plan, announced on Tuesday by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, calls for building an infrastructure to capture and retain storm water before it reaches the sewer system and
title: $1.5 Billion Plan Would Cut Sewage Flow Into City Waters

body: If you need to raise money, as arts organizations perpetually do, you might as well make the exercise fun for your supporters, who are constantly being hit up for donations these days. The directors of MATA, the new-music festival that has become a year-round concert series, has come up with a lively approach. Its benefit concert at the Chelsea Art
title: MUSIC REVIEW; New-Music Benefit Becomes The Art Itself

body: The Environmental Protection Agency has designated Newtown Creek, between Brooklyn and Queens, a Superfund site, promising a thorough environmental cleanup of a long-neglected waterway that was once one of the busiest hubs of industrial activity in the city. The Superfund designation, which was announced on Monday by the agency's regional
title: U.S. Cleanup Is Set for Creek Long Polluted By Industry

body: Like many New Yorkers, the people of Brooklyn Heights have something of a love-hate relationship with the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. On the one hand, the highway is the bane of the neighborhood, carrying trucks whose startling rumbles often wake the sleeping, and spewing dust and fumes onto leafy streets named Cranberry, Pineapple and Willow. But
title: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS JOURNAL; As Aging B.Q.E. Faces Reconstruction, Ideas Turn to Tunnels

body: HOW could he possibly relinquish the lease on a $714 rent-stabilized one-bedroom? Everyone told Gary Parker he was crazy. But he was the one living the reality behind the cheap rent. His railroad apartment in South Park Slope, Brooklyn, was noisy, dark and badly maintained. He longed for a better quality of life. Mr. Parker, who grew up near
title: THE HUNT; Because Dirt-Cheap Has Its Downsides

body: Pop Ben Sisario For American listeners who encountered them in the 1980s and '90s, the records of the Japanese musician known as MERZBOW (real name: Masami Akita) were pretty much the most abrasive thing imaginable: guttural electronic buzz saws, screeches that seemed as if they were being transmitted into your brain by some wicked alien
title: THE WEEK AHEAD | SEPT 19- SEPT 25

But vacation time is over already. On Wednesday the orchestra swings back into action -- literally -- with an opening-night gala that includes
title: THE WEEK AHEAD | SEPT 19- SEPT 25

title: Weekend Miser

body: Dates are subject to change. SEPTEMBER LUNCHTIME CONCERTS Even in a better economy, who can pass up a free concert, especially when the performers are first-rate and the repertory is compelling? Following on free lunchtime Beethoven and Bach cycles of recent years, the Miller Theater now sets its sights on 20th-century American composers, performed
title: New Faces, Old Masters And a Shiny 'Ring'

body: THE history of Western classical music is rife with forgotten side roads, populated by composers and styles overlooked, marginalized or otherwise neglected. The Propensity of Sound, a five-concert series that the Issue Project Room in Gowanus, Brooklyn, will mount in late September, follows one such unfamiliar path. Presented in collaboration with
title: Dispatches From the Edge Of the Sonic Frontier

body: No one could turn out the lights at the ''performative discussion'' between the provocative performance artist Ann Liv Young and the artist A. L. Steiner at the sunlit MoMAP.S. 1 in Long Island City, Queens, on Sunday afternoon. But as it turned out, the mood couldn't have been less like its subject: Ms. Young's fraught and much-discussed
title: Provocateur Returns to P.S. 1, but Not to Provoke

body: The performer-writer Ann Liv Young belongs to the movement in the arts that was labeled Sensation in the 1990s. She performed ''Snow White'' naked, apart from a Disney mask on her face, while heavily pregnant. Dildos and masturbation have been part of her theatrical fare. At MoMAP.S. 1 in February she insulted a fellow artist's work (accompanied by
title: DANCE REVIEW; This Time the Trouble Isn't Wicked Stepsisters

body: International THAI OPPOSITION Retreats Into Silence In Udon Thani, the base of much of Thailand's antigovernment opposition, the Thai government appears to have made little headway in calming or winning over its opponents. Scores of people are in hiding, and critics of the government have retreated into silence. PAGE A4 OPTIMISM ON MIDEAST TALKS
title: Inside The Times

title: The Listings

title: The Listings

Round up some vintage duds and get ready to dance some jive and bop and do the stroll, beginning at 10

body: Pop Ben Sisario When CLINIC emerged from Liverpool in the late 1990s, it was with all the abrasion and absurdist theatricality of classic art-rock. Members of the band wore doctors' scrubs and surgical masks onstage and played claustrophobic tunes with prickly, repetitive guitars and whiffs of scary organ and melodica. You could take it all as a
title: THE WEEK AHEAD | AUG. 15--AUG. 21

Its new-wave music is clever and joyful. With Belinda Carlisle (of the Go-Go's). At 7:30 p.m., Asser Levy/Seaside Park,
title: The Listings

body: ON most Sunday nights Issue Project Room -- a dark, narrow performance space less than a block from the ever-festering Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn -- is occupied by a cabal of tinkerers. Crates of equipment in tow, they snake cables across the floor, joining laptops, projectors, video-game consoles, synthesizers and other devices into a throbbing,
title: The Tech Jam: Anything Can Happen, and Usually Does

body: THOUGH it resides in a prime example of traditional museum architecture -- a Beaux-Arts building designed in 1893 by McKim, Mead & White -- there is little stale or stodgy about the Brooklyn Museum. For more than a century the museum has been one of the country's most important cultural institutions, and for more than a decade it has also courted
title: Sketching A Future For Brooklyn Museum

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Alice Austen House Outdoor events: On Friday, ''Rock the House,'' music with a D.J. beginning at 7 p.m. and live bands from 8 to 10 p.m. On Saturday at 6:30 p.m., a dance program built around the themes of nature and the life of Isadora Duncan, presented by the Isadora Duncan Dance Company, the youth dance ensemble
title: SPARE TIMES

body: Jazz Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music. - Ralph Alessi Quartet (Wednesday) Ralph Alessi, an adventurous and crisply proficient trumpeter, has a new album, ''Cognitive Dissonance'' (Cam Jazz), featuring the same excellent rhythm partners featured here, each a bandleader in his own right: the pianist Jason Moran, the bassist
title: The Listings

body: The salt marshes are long gone from Newtown Creek, and so are most of the birds and fish. Now, this waterway straddling Brooklyn and Queens is dotted by bulkheads and containment booms meant to keep oil away from the shoreline while underground pumps work around the clock removing petroleum from adjacent land. Decades in the making and confined to
title: Where Brooklyn And Queens Meet, A Quiet Parallel To the Gulf Spill

body: The band's name, 40Twenty, has nothing to do with the John Deere 4020 family-farm tractor, extraordinary long-range vision or the numerical code for smoking marijuana. It's a Brooklyn jazz group with the trombonist Jacob Garchik, the pianist Jacob Sacks, the bassist Dave Ambrosio and the drummer Vinnie Sperrazza. The name refers to the 40-20 set, a
title: MUSIC REVIEW; Two Weeks, One Stage: The Forging Of a Sound

body: THE BREUCKELEN DISTILLING COMPANY is joining a long -- and long-gone -- tradition of Brooklyn booze-making, though its equipment does not resemble the gritty clandestine stills that one imagines existed during Prohibition. Its still is a 16-foot-tall gleaming copper unit that cost roughly $100,000, and is located in a clean, spacious storefront on
title: OPEN AND SHUT; Chronicle of a Changing City

body: Jazz Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music. Marcus Strickland, an industrious young tenor and soprano saxophonist,
title: The Listings

body: With our views blocked by concrete and metal, it is easy to forget that New York is surrounded by water. That's why on Saturday, the third annual City of Water Day Festival will let the masses ferry, paddle, row, canoe and kayak their way to the city's waterfronts for a full day of free activities sponsored by the Metropolitan Waterfront Alliance
title: WEEKEND MISER; City of Water Day Festival

Continuing exhibitions include ''Race to the End of the
title: Spare Times

body: Kickstarter is a concept: a Web site that puts together creative types seeking money with backers willing to chip in micro- and macro-payments, a way to crowd-source the financing of ideas. Started last year, the company has become an unexpected influence on indie culture, a new model for a D.I.Y. generation. And on Friday Kickstarter will also
title: For Web-Financed Film Projects, a Curtain Rises

body: THE Fourth of July is approaching rapidly, and just behind it comes the deluge: summer shows at every turn, of all stripes. There are eclectic festivals, outdoor park concerts, big-tent nostalgia-rock tours, and sweaty shows in out-of-the-way spaces with questionable commitment to air-conditioning. Still, even the most taxing of summer shows are
title: Oh, Say, Can You Hear?

body: To get to the city pool in Brooklyn's Gowanus neighborhood in the 1970s, a swimmer ran a gantlet. The pool sat amid factories and workshops, the streets around it crowded with trucks. Sex workers met clients near the gates, on Douglass Street. Still, clutching towels, local residents in need of a dip knew where to go, a block from the noxious
title: CITY ROOM; A Reprieve For an Oasis In Brooklyn With an Edge

body: Turns out the Gowanus Canal is socially as well as environmentally inhospitable. Just two weeks after announcing its intention to do a summer's worth of programming at the Bklyn Yard, an event space by the canal, Sunday Best, a weekly electronica party, will move on, its founders said. Though licensing for alcohol and other details were proceeding
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; Bklyn Yard Party Now at a New Location

body: Oh, the days of $3 drive-in movies, how our love lives (and wallets) miss them. Well, the Saturday night Sci-Fi Summer film series indoors at the Coney Island Museum can be the modern couple's next-best alternative. This weekend the program presents ''Attack of the 50-Foot Woman'' (1958), and continues every Saturday at 8:30 p.m. through Sept. 18,
title: THE WEEKEND MISER; Sci-Fi Summer Films, a Free Hip Hop Old School Party, and the UnFancy Food Show

With Partyface. At 6:30 p.m., Mercury Lounge, 217

body: Pop/Jazz Nate Chinen The irrepressible avant-garde composer and multireedist ANTHONY BRAXTON turned 65 a couple of weeks ago, and he's celebrating with his usual panache. ''Tri-Centric Modeling: Past, Present and Future'' is a two-day festival dedicated to his music and legacy, featuring Mr. Braxton and a powerful array of protégés and peers. It
title: THE WEEK AHEAD | JUNE 13--JUNE 19

body: The party will go on. A week after the Bklyn Yard, the popular performance space on the banks of the Gowanus Canal, announced that it was closing, Justin Carter, a D. J. and promoter who has produced weekly events there, said his party, Sunday Best, would continue. ''We've worked it out so we're going to be able to have a shot at it,'' Mr. Carter
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; Brooklyn Party Space To Return In a Flash

body: CENTENNIAL BEE-DAY PARTY In Kafka's ''Metamorphosis'' Gregor Samsa awakens to discover that he has become an enormous cockroach. While that may be among the most unwelcome transformations on record, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden will offer one on Saturday that's shorter, sweeter and sunnier: children changing themselves into bees. The process is part
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: Herein, Herring Herring season, with fresh fish from the Netherlands, starts on June 9. The herring will be served at the Oyster Bar in Grand Central Terminal through June 25; (212) 490-6650. It will be sold at Russ & Daughters, 179 East Houston Street (Allen Street); (212) 475-4880, through July, while supplies last. A herring buffet will be
title: Calendar

body: Christina Nieves's life revolves around a handful of blocks in Brooklyn: Drop off her 4-year-old daughter and 2-year-old son at the Strong Place day care center. Make sure her 75-year-old grandmother, who uses a wheelchair, makes it to lunch at the Gowanus Senior Center. Then, on too many occasions to count, take her son, who is asthmatic and prone
title: Budget Cuts Hit a Brooklyn Area Over and Over

body: The Bklyn Yard, above, an outdoor arts and performance space along the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, is shutting down. For four years it held concerts by big indie names, including Dan Deacon and José González, and was a home for Sunday Best, a popular dance party. But in an announcement on Friday on the Yard's Web site (bklynyard.com), MeanRed, the
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; Promoters Scramble as Bklyn Yard Loses Its Lease

body: IN the claustrophobic confines of New York City, nothing marks the beginning of summer like an open-air dance party. And in South Brooklyn on the Sunday of Memorial Day weekend, summer commenced at an event space known as the Bklyn Yard. body: IN the claustrophobic confines of New York City, nothing marks the beginning of summer like an open-air dance party. And in South Brooklyn on the Sunday of Memorial Day weekend, summer commenced at an event space known as the Bklyn Yard. In a grove of leafy trees, hundreds of women (exposed shoulders, gladiator sandals) and men (straw hats, crisp
title: Celebration at the Edge of Decay

body: International U.S. RELATIONS PLAYED ROLE IN PRIME MINISTER'S DOWNFALL When Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama of Japan abruptly stepped down Wednesday, largely for his failure to move an American air base off Okinawa, he was essentially admitting he had not won popular support for a prominent campaign pledge: ending Japan's postwar dependence on the
title: Inside the Times

body: YOU are hanging onto plastic knobs a dozen feet off the ground in an old Daily News garage in Brooklyn. Music pumps, and crowds of people cheer. But if you close your eyes for a moment, you might imagine you're hundreds of feet up, hanging off a cliff in Yosemite National Park. title: URBAN ATHLETE; Climbing the Walls in Brooklyn

body: JOHN AMEROSO didn't hoe the rows of vegetables that help feed the Bronx at the Padre Plaza Success Garden in the borough's Mott Haven section. He didn't pick any tomatoes from the vines at the Brooklyn Rescue Mission's farm. And he didn't turn the composting bins that kept East New York Farms! fertile ground for collards, cilantro and chard. But
title: An Urban Farming Pioneer Sows His Own Legacy

body: How do you one-up a Dumpster pool? For David Belt, a developer who created a stir last summer by installing do-it-yourself swimming pools made from Dumpsters in a semi-secret location in Brooklyn, the answer was once again in trash. His latest project, called ''Glassphemy!,'' is billed as a psychological recycling experiment. The idea is to make
title: A Smashing Idea: Eco-Friendly Aggression

title: THE WEEK AHEAD | MAY 9--MAY 15

body: The Gowanus neighborhood of Brooklyn, the city's latest industrial desert turned cultural outpost, makes for a pleasant afternoon's wander. The namesake canal, while it holds tons of poisonous stuff, is serene and calming. Things still do get a little post-apocalyptic: the weird drone of a cement factory, wide empty streets dotted with used
title: LOCAL STOP | GOWANUS; A Canal Zone Comes Into Its Own

body: ALONG the East and Hudson Rivers, on stretches of Jamaica Bay, and by the banks of the Gowanus Canal, formerly neglected industrial land has recently been reborn as parkland, or will be before long. But in Brighton Beach, a dense enclave by Coney Island at Brooklyn's southern tip, no rebirth was required: the shoreline has always been a popular
title: LIVING IN | BRIGHTON BEACH, BROOKLYN; Views to Fill the Eye, Not Empty the Wallet

body: ''He's the Rembrandt of 72nd Street!'' a yellow cab driver yelled at a man on the sidewalk sketching the 72nd Street subway station last Wednesday on the Upper West Side. Not quite: Rembrandt did not use city subway maps as his canvases. But the Rembrandt of 72nd Street does: Enrico Miguel Thomas, who can be found nearly every day outside the
title: CITY ROOM; For a Miniature Canvas, Maybe He'd Try MetroCards

body: Pie-making is in the DNA of Melissa (at center in photo) and Emily Elsen (at left). Their grandmother baked pies for their mother's restaurant in Hecla, S.D., and it was from her that they learned their craft. And now, after a year of baking pies for a growing list of clients, they have opened a bakery and cafe in Gowanus, Brooklyn. There's an open
title: FOOD STUFF; Plenty of Tradition But No Blackbirds In These Sisters' Pies

body: A music review last Tuesday about a concert presented by Issue Project Room at the Old American Can Factory in Brooklyn misidentified the neighborhood in which the Factory is located. It is Gowanus, not Carroll Gardens.

title: Spare Times: For Children

title: MUSIC REVIEW; An All-Day Concert, but Only One Piece Was Performed

title: SQUARE FEET; An Empty Warehouse Holds Dreams of Industrial Jobs

body: The former headquarters of the National Packing Box Factory on the banks of the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn have not pumped out a packing box in decades. But since 2005, the sturdy brick building has housed a workshop of a different sort: Proteus Gowanus, an ever-changing cultural organism that describes itself as an ''interdisciplinary gallery and
title: Along the Gowanus Canal, an Evolving Gallery of Curiosities (Muck Included)

title: ARCHITECTURE REVIEW | 'RISING CURRENTS: PROJECTS FOR NEW YORK'S WATERFRONT'; The Future: A More Watery New York

title: The Listings: Pop

body: To the Editor: Re ''Cleaning the Gowanus'' (editorial, March 4): The Environmental Protection Agency's decision to designate the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn as a Superfund site is bitterly disappointing to many residents and civic organizations in Gowanus that vastly preferred New York City's Superfund alternative plan over the federal approach. The
title: LETTER; The Gowanus Canal Cleanup: A Community View

author: Andrew Cotto lives in Carroll Gardens and teaches composition, over the racket of jackhammers, at the ASA Institute in Downtown Brooklyn. Join a reader discussion of his rant at nytimes.com/cityroom.
body: WE left Manhattan for Brooklyn in 1997. Even then, before it was the rage, it felt like a destination. We kept track of all the things the neighborhoods of Brooklyn had over the metropolis of Manhattan: actual diversity, affordable restaurants, more parking and less pretension. But the best thing, no doubt, every time, was the sky. Brooklyn had
title: COMPLAINT BOX BROOKLYN RISING; They're Stealing My Sky

body: To the Editor: Re ''Cleaning the Gowanus'' (editorial, March 4): Your editorial about the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn is right about one thing: the point of New York City's alternative to Superfund was the cleanup. We are as committed to that goal now as when we submitted our comprehensive plan last July, and we'll work with the Environmental
title: LETTER; The Gowanus Canal

body: Drone chords are accommodating and diplomatic. They're the secret handshake between Westerners and Easterners, soft-eyed hippies and aggro noise merchants, improvisers and composers. They're also totems, full of their own significance. And bullies. They don't complain or explain. If they're in the music's foreground, they'll blot out everything
title: MUSIC REVIEW | GLISSANDO BIN LADEN; Violins Face Off Against Laptops in a Friendly Improvisational Duel

body: THE area around the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn is home to painters and prostitutes, auto mechanics and ornithologists. After the canal was designated a Superfund site last week, nearly 200 readers submitted their visions of it online -- in photography, paintings and other media. The images show the canal at dusk, the oil patches that glide on the
title: Gowanus: The Beauty Of Goop

body: The rain had stopped; the streets were empty. A block from the Gowanus Canal, a woman called Terri squinted into the headlights of passing cars, searched for clients and found none. Her head was wrapped in a powder-blue scarf. The white towers of the Wyckoff Houses rose behind her. She had worked these streets in Brooklyn for years, as the
title: It's Polluted, but the Canal Is Home, and Inspiration

body: The Environmental Protection Agency designated the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn a Superfund site on Tuesday and announced plans to clean up more than a century's worth of noxious pollutants there. The decision ended a contentious debate and was a blow to the Bloomberg administration, which had proposed a cleanup without such a designation. The city
title: E.P.A. Readies Cleanup Plan For Gowanus

title: SQUARE FEET | THE 30-MINUTE INTERVIEW; Robert I. Toll

title: The Listings

body: They honor stickball tournaments and dance teachers, doughnut-store openings or New Yorkers reaching the century mark. They spread good will, honor bravery and service, and cement political alliances. Every year, writing in formal prose with 14th-century flourishes, the presidents of the five boroughs distribute hundreds of proclamations and
title: With the Stroke of a Pen, Honoring the Little Known, if Only for a Day

title: THE HUNT; Plugged In and Happy

title: The Listings: Pop

body: No one minded that the Moritz Von Oswald Trio had five members when it made its American debut on Saturday night at Le Poisson Rouge, part of the Unsound Festival New York and the Wordless Music series at the club. The trio is an alliance of techno and ambient disc jockeys and programmers doing what they don't do in D.J. booths or remix studios:
title: MUSIC REVIEW | THE MORITZ VON OSWALD TRIO; Ambient Techno Gets the Improvised, Live Touch

body: THE WATSON TWINS ''Talking to You, Talking to Me'' (Vanguard) Contemplating the title of the second full-length album by the Watson Twins can be a hall-of-mirrors experience. Who's talking to whom? Which one is doing the talking? Are they talking to each other? You talkin' to me? Chandra and Leigh Watson, identical twins originally from Louisville,
title: CRITICS' CHOICE; New CDs

body: Were you to guess in advance which instrument Dayve Hawk -- the one-man band Memory Tapes -- would be playing during what he described as his first American live show, the answer probably wouldn't have been guitar. But there it was on Wednesday night at the Bell House in Gowanus, Brooklyn, slung around his neck, an unexpected accent piece. Guitar
title: MUSIC REVIEW | MEMORY TAPES; One-Man Band (and a Few Surprises)

body: Panhandlers in this city are often ignored, stiffed, even reviled, but sometimes, if they hang around long enough and take the right approach, they can work themselves not only into the wallets, but also into the hearts of those they solicit. Such was the case with Tom, the Concierge of Court Street. Tom was the guy who held the door for you at
title: In Brooklyn, Court Street Pays Tribute to a Fixture

title: The Listings

body: The Patti Smith tangle atop Victoria Legrand's head was quaking something fierce on Tuesday night while all around her stillness was the move. Otherwise the most energy emanated from flickering neon lights trapped inside trees of white fur and occasionally the small bursts of life from her Beach House band mate, Alex Scally, or the touring drummer,
title: MUSIC REVIEW | BEACH HOUSE; Woozy, Moody Pop Played at a Resting Pulse Rate

title: The Listings

Allen -- along with Luis Pedomo on piano and Rudy Royston on drums. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Jazz

author: Risa Chubinsky lives in Park Slope and works as a subsidiary rights coordinator at Penguin Group (U.S.A.) in the West Village. Comment on her rant at nytimes.com/cityroom.
body: As a 5-foot-4, dark-haired Jewish girl in her early 20s, I was never a minority in New York City until I moved to Park Slope, where I seem to be one of the few childless residents. While it might be enjoyable for outsiders to read books like ''Prospect Park West,'' which details the mommy culture run amok, it is a whole other sensation to be stuck
title: COMPLAINT BOX | BABY BARFLIES; When Toddlers Belly Up to the Bar

body: POP Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. BON IVER (Thursday) Bon Iver is the alias of the singer-songwriter Justin Vernon, who famously recorded his debut album, ''For Emma, Forever Ago'' (Jagjaguwar), in an isolated Wisconsin cabin in deep winter. Unsurprisingly, the resultant folk songs are contemplative and heavy with longing,
title: The Listings

body: Jose Chirino, a 10th grader in Brooklyn with shoulder-length hair and a thin mustache, says flatly that his high school was his last choice. ''They're experimenting on us,'' he said, recalling his first impression of the Green School in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, which laces an environmental theme into most of its coursework. title: Teaching Green, Beyond Recycling

author: E-mail: habitats@nytimes.com
body: GOWANUS HOUSES, a complex of 14 red-brick buildings that sits not far from its namesake canal in Brooklyn, opened on a June day in 1949, flush with the optimism that wreathed new housing developments for low-income New Yorkers. Among the 1,100-plus original families was a young couple named Leslie and Victoria Baskett Flowers. He worked in a
title: HABITATS | BOERUM HILL, BROOKLYN; The Leader Of the Cheers

body: Markets Head Indoors The Brooklyn Flea will move into a new winter indoor market on Jan. 9 in the Williamsburg Savings Bank building at 1 Hanson Place in Fort Greene. It will be open Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., through March 28. After that it will shift to its two outdoor locations. On Jan. 10 from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m., the seasonal
